# HTML5 Style Guide ## General In authoring environments, indent nested tags with 'soft tabs' of two spaces. (These can be stripped when actually serving the page to a client) ### Text The only characters that should be escaped are '<', '>', '&', which have named entities, and any special whitespace characters, which should be escaped using their numerical code.. Good: & > <   (non-breaking space) – (em-dash) £ Bad:   (named entities can invalidate xml/rss/json and are a pain) &#XXX; (whatever the number for < is) (whatever the hex variant is). ## Tags Use lowercase Avoid mis-matched tags. Bad: link ###Attributes Always use double quotes where there's content Use the shorter style for boolean attributes. Good Bad Empty tags No need for a trailing slash. Good:

Not-so-good:

###HTML page structure: Always start with minimal doctype and include , and tags (even though they're not required). Good: ##Text-level semantics ### Citations Only use for the titles of books, films, journal articles & plays. Don't bother for the titles of blog posts, news articles, wikipedia entries, magazine titles or anything else. Never use for the names of people or products. ### Emphasis Only use to mark words or short phrases which would be stressed when spoken aloud. Good: He really hated it The music was loud Bad: She asked the person for a ticket. In Star Wars, he had a hit. ### Strong emphasis Only use strong to mark key words (usually nouns) that are especially relevant. In practice: rarely use it. Good: The conference was about user-experience design. You searched for Christmas. Bad: She really, really loved it. Search matches: "She loved Christmas…" ### Italics Use for any cases not covered by or where being typographically-marked (typically with italics) is essential to the meaning of the text and isn't just styling. Typically 'an alternate voice'. In practice: use rarely. Good: It might work. It might not. Bad: She loved it - use I read Macbeth - use
